answers.answer: In answer to your questions.1. No; 2. Yes; 3. a proper syringe would invariably draw a drop of blood; 4. even if it had HIV+ blood in it, your chances of getting HIV are very small - 0.3% is the risk for needle stick injuries in health workers.Dalyk - I would advise 2 things. Firstly, you are showing excessive paranoia - you should probably find a mental health professional to discuss this with. Secondly, you should read up about HIV transmission if that is what you fear. You cannot catch HIV from toilet splash backs or from eating without washing your hands. You may get other infections but not HIV.Good luck and I hope that helps.
